Warlock.name: Warlock
Warlock.description:
At the origin of Avalon, its creators were primarily focused on developing versatile armaments, designed for all situations, to repel or kill each enemy of the Anathema. Over the months of struggle, numerous armour prototypes were designed, tested, and sometimes field-tested with varying results, sometimes positive, sometimes failures. This is how the Druid and Psion meta-armours were developed, and the prototypes of the Pistolero and Swashbuckler meta-armours were abandoned. But one meta-armour remained in the prototype phase for a long time, neither abandoned nor deployed in the field: the Warlock meta-armour.

This armour is based on one of the qualities of the Anathema: its ability to distort and manipulate temporal rules. By collecting alpha element, the dark material found under the shadows, and subjecting it to numerous tests, the engineers of the Giant section and the scientists of the Cyclops section understood that the material could change its temporal state through certain manipulations. The alpha element is thus capable of regenerating by moving back a few seconds in time or, conversely, being displaced rapidly by moving forward a few seconds into the future. It can even be duplicated for a few moments, existing twice at the same time. Building on this discovery, Gauvain and Dagonnet attempted to develop a meta-armour, composed mainly of alpha element, that could manipulate its own temporal state and thus repair itself by moving back in time or move rapidly and replicate for a few seconds. Unfortunately, the integrity of the equipment was quickly compromised after temporal manipulation, and worse still, the wearer suffered numerous physical and mental repercussions that left them quickly exhausted and almost mad.

Month after month, the two knights of the Round Table conducted tests without success but did not want to abandon this promising concept. Surprisingly, it was Sagramor who found the solution. Responsible for supervising the first trials conducted by members of his section, the knight of the Round Table quickly realized that what damaged the wearers of the meta-armour was the fact that they did not change temporal state while the armour did. They were thus violently transported from one time to another, and both body and mind were disturbed. For the wearers to follow the meta-armour in these changes, they needed to be fitted with a complete, hermetic suit composed mainly of alpha element and connected to tiny bodily implants made of the same material and distributed throughout the body... with the obvious implications for their hope.

With this solution in mind, tests were conducted again. The suit and the implants of dark material allowed the wearer to better resist, and surprisingly, the integrity of the armour seemed to increase, as if the wearer and the equipment were in true symbiosis. Unfortunately, after days and days of tests, Dagonnet and Gauvain realized that if the testers no longer suffered physical and mental repercussions, they seemed to become detached from time over the course of the trials.

Thus, the few knights designated to test the prototype in the field began to experience small memory losses and felt out of phase, as if they no longer belonged to the correct timeline. A minor evil compared to the martial qualities of the meta-armour.



The Warlock meta-armour was designed to quickly take down Avalon's targets and retreat just as quickly. It is a martial, violent armour, but its use remains dangerous. The wearers of the Warlock know this well and use it with caution, as it sometimes seems to cause heavy changes in their person. They know that each use of one of the meta-armour's three capabilities causes a different effect on them, which they will have to endure at some point.

Although classified as a third-generation armour, the composition of the Warlock is unique within the entire arsenal of Avalon. Composed almost entirely of fine layers of alpha element, it exudes an impressive sense of anxiety, and its knotty appearance further reinforces this aspect. Lightweight, with substantial armour due to its composition and a powerful alpha energy core, it nevertheless has a rather weak force field, disrupted by the mass of alpha element that constitutes the armour. Each of the Warlock's capabilities is also very energy-intensive and requires precise management by the wearer to avoid running out at the wrong moment, as while the meta-armour can cancel damage by returning in time, the energy does not seem to regenerate in this way.

In appearance, the Warlock is a dark, long, and unsettling armour. The dark material covers it almost entirely, leaving only rare armour plates visible, and the whole seems to absorb light over a few centimeters. Many of its wearers try to improve its appearance with ornaments to make it less repulsive, but the alpha element always seems to dull these changes.

Finally, the capabilities of the Warlock meta-armour make it truly unique, and its operation can sometimes be difficult to understand for knights who have not tried it. To simplify, the Warlock only manipulates time on itself. The world around does not change; only the Warlock undergoes this temporal return. Thus, for example, when the armour moves back in time a few seconds, it returns to its previous place and state, but everything around it, the environment, people, and monsters, does not experience any return to the past. Temporal manipulation is a personal power that acts only on the armour and its wearer, but can be applied in many ways.



The Warlock meta-armour has three capabilities. They are associated with repercussions that must be taken into account and activated by the PC themselves.
Warlock.forwardDescription:
The meta-armour is capable of accelerating time on itself to move more quickly.

The knight's movement ranges – whether normal movement or those granted by running, jumping, or flying modules – are increased by one level up to a maximum equal to long range. A contact range thus becomes a short range, a short range becomes a medium range, and a medium range becomes a long range. Beyond this, the integrity of the armour is too compromised for the AI to authorize such movement. Movement in a vehicle, movements granted by Level 1 or 3 Movement OD, and the teleportation module are not affected by this capability.
Warlock.recordDescription:
Thanks to this mode, the knight can manipulate time to record an attack he is about to perform and make a past double appear briefly to reproduce it up to 6 seconds later. Thus, he can record an attack from a given turn, move and strike in the next turn, while reproducing the recorded attack.

By activating this mode, the knight triggers the recording of the next attack he will perform during this turn. He must activate the mode before making his attack. It can be performed with a weapon or a module. In the next turn, he can perform his normal actions and activate the mode without any energy cost to reproduce exactly his attack performed in the previous turn, with a double of himself, like a remanence, appearing to strike or shoot again.

The recorded attack action is reproduced identically. This means that the attack roll, damage or violence roll, range, and effects are exactly the same (even if the player spent a point of heroism to maximize damage). The energy spent to increase damage or add effects, as well as ammunition, do not need to be deducted again. However, the attack can be directed at the same target or another. Consequently, if the attack roll is not sufficient to hit, the attack simply fails and will have been recorded for nothing.

Reproducing an attack costs no EP.

Recording the attack as well as reproducing it costs no action. However, only one attack can be recorded per turn.

The attack recorded in one turn must be reproduced in the next turn, otherwise it and the energy are lost.
Warlock.rewindDescription:
In a colorless flash followed by a nearly invisible rapid movement, the meta-armour (and consequently its wearer) can disappear and return to the state and position it had exactly 6 seconds ago, recovering what it had lost during that time or canceling what had been inflicted on it. The environment around does not change; only the Warlock undergoes this temporal return.

Activating this capability thus allows for the following effects:

- Return to the health points possessed less than 6 seconds ago (or the previous game turn), whether they are lower or higher.

- Return to the armour points possessed less than 6 seconds ago (or the previous game turn), whether they are lower or higher.

- Cancel a severe injury received less than 6 seconds ago (or the previous game turn).

- Recover the ammunition(s) of a module (and only a module) used less than 6 seconds ago (or the previous game turn).

- Recover a nod(s) used less than 6 seconds ago (or the previous game turn).

- Instantly move to the position from 6 seconds ago (or the previous game turn).

All effects activate simultaneously. It is up to the PC to regulate their scores and equipment. Hope points and energy points are not affected by these effects. Broken weapons and all equipment other than nods and module ammunition used are not affected either.

Note: The effect is personal and is restricted to the meta-armour itself, its wearer, its weapons, its modules, and the equipment located in its pack. What is present around the meta-armour or in contact with it (such as an ally) is not affected. If an element prevents the return of the meta-armour and its wearer to their previous position, they simply approach that position as closely as possible without colliding.

The knight must activate it during their combat turn. They must wait 6 seconds after a Rewind to activate it again. This means that in a conflict phase, they can only perform one Rewind per turn.
Warlock.contrecoupsDescription:
The power of the Warlock is not without consequences. These two drawbacks are cumulative: one is constant, the other can be triggered after using one of the Rewind, Forward, or Record abilities.

TEMPORAL MALFUNCTION

All projectile weapons or those that are too technologically advanced suffer malfunctions or serious incidents when the wearer of the Warlock meta-armour uses their abilities.

The arsenal prohibits Warlock meta-armour wearers from acquiring ranged weapons. Additionally, they are forbidden from receiving contact weapons with 5 or more effects, including enhancement effects (excluding prestige weapons and effects granted by the Forge applied to the weapon).

TEMPORAL PARADOX

Using the abilities of this meta-armour strains the temporal integrity of the character. Each time they activate one of their three meta-armour abilities during a scene or conflict phase, the character must note it. Once the scene or phase is over, they can erase their notes.

After the first use, each time they use one of their three meta-armour abilities, the character must make a base Composure or Aggression test, without considering overdrives, to resist the temporal effects. The difficulty of the test is equal to the number of uses of the meta-armour abilities during the scene or conflict phase.

If the test fails, the character must roll 2D6 and refer to the table in the atlas.

- Tear: The character's body is torn through time. They receive a random severe wound that applies automatically.

- Malfunction: The FF of the meta-armour drops to 0 for 1D3 turns.

- Disintegration: The character's meta-armour takes 3D6 points of damage without FF. The Rewind ability cannot cancel these damages.

- Disorientation: The knight is mentally disoriented. They suffer a loss of 1D6 hope points.

- Disappearance: In a flash, the character disappears from the scene and only returns at the end.

- Fragmentation: The character suffers damage to their psyche and forgets who they are for 1D6 turns. The GM and players must improvise.

- Incident: The character takes 4D6 points of damage directly to their health. The Rewind ability cannot cancel these damages.

- Siphon: The character's energy is instantly reduced by 6D6 points.

- Jolt: For 1D6 turns, the meta-armour constantly jumps through time. They must remove 2 successes from each of their tests.
Warlock.n0EvolutionsDescription: Now, the EP costs of the Rewind and Record modes are reduced by 3.
Warlock.n1EvolutionsDescription:
Now, the Rewind mode can be activated just after (not before, nor during) an action of another PC or NPC, even if the knight should be unable to perform an action or if they have been killed. Effects inflicted by NPCs and that should persist, such as domination, control, and isolation, are ignored by the PC.

Note: The knight must still wait 6 seconds before reactivating the Rewind mode and can only reactivate it once the full game turn has passed.
Warlock.n2EvolutionsDescription: The armour is better stabilized in temporal terms. Now, the character can reroll their roll on the temporal paradoxes table and choose between the two results.

Shaman.name: Shaman
Shaman.description:
The Shaman model was designed to exploit the potential of the artificial intelligences of the Knight's meta-armours. Very quickly, the knights realized that if the AIs that accompanied them could act, help them directly in combat or simply on missions, they would be formidable assistants, as efficient and loyal as squires.

Thus, the Squire model AIs were studied, manipulated, and tested. Merlin and Gauvain incorporated them into artificial bodies with control, movement, and independence capabilities. Unfortunately, if these intelligences constitute very efficient auxiliaries in the mastery of a meta-armour, they seem too self-aware to endure being transferred into a body without suffering serious psychological and psychic backlash. The discovery of a new body, the taking of freedom, the impression of really existing were for the Squire model AIs like the revealers of flaws that had always existed in them. Some of those that had been given a body were unable to leave it and preferred to commit suicide or flee rather than be dispossessed of their shell. It is Gauvain who, through the tests, noticed that the AIs gradually attached themselves to their bodies and that their minds linked to them more or less slowly. This phenomenon was named 'imprinting'.

Imprinting is dangerous for AIs because it binds them forever to a body. With the aim of making these intelligences field assistants while avoiding the imprinting phenomenon, Gauvain and Merlin decided to create a new meta-armour capable of materializing an AI for a time, in the form of an ephemeral body, modeled on that of the wearer's meta-armour. The replicated shell of the meta-armour would allow the intelligence to more easily endure its materialization by inhabiting a body it already knows, and its ephemeral existence would limit or even prevent the imprinting phenomenon. It could even materialize in several bodies to act better and more quickly. This is how the Shaman meta-armour was created and tested for a long year before leaving the arsenal.



The Shaman meta-armour possesses armour, a good force field, and a reliable alpha energy reactor. A third-generation armour, it has a light appearance, almost that of an armoured suit at the shoulders, torso, and forearms. Regularly, Shaman wearers adorn their meta-armour with flourishes, such as fabric panels, crests, or feathers, so that their AI can easily identify with the equipment it occupies. It should also be noted that the AI of this meta-armour model is not standardized like its counterparts. Each AI, simply named 'Shaman AI', has an unparalleled consciousness and autonomy, even within the largest robotics companies. An interesting detail, each AI receives its name in agreement with the knight after a long discussion, or even several days of cohabitation. Just like Guinevere and Arthur, it often happens that the artificial intelligence and the hero bond emotionally, to the point that a form of love or solid friendship can be born between the two.

The Shaman meta-armour operates on the principle of materializing its AI into one or more bodies made of nanomachines to assist the knight in the field. Unlike the Druid meta-armour, the bodies materialized in Ascension mode are perfectly autonomous and can perform complex tasks, without range limits. When the meta-armour evolves, these bodies can even be materialized when the knight is out of their meta-armour.



The Shaman meta-armour can use two modes that exclude each other. One cannot be used at the same time as the other.
Shaman.ascensionDescription:
The knight can materialize their AI in a body named 'Ascension'. This body is an exact replica of the knight's meta-armour, with its modules, its total and current values, but without its weapons.

The knight can materialize their AI in Ascension mode. To materialize it, they must grant it a portion of their own EP temporarily subtracted from their total. The total value of the knight's EP is reduced by this amount for the duration of the AI's materialization. The AI in Ascension mode has the same character sheet as the knight (same aspects, characteristics, OD, derived values, total scores, FF, etc.), but it does not have a health score and is destroyed when its AP falls to 0. It can, of course, be repaired before its AP reaches 0.

It has the same modules as the knight (which can be armament modules), the same number of current nods and ammunition, but not its weapons, nor its smart grenades. The intelligence thus incorporated into a body acts independently, without any range limit, and obeys the knight's orders if it considers them justified. It can refuse an order that it deems unjust or inappropriate. It is not the GM who plays this AI, but the PC who must try to play it in the most appropriate way, according to the AI's personality.
Shaman.ascensionDuration: One scene or one phase of conflict, can be prolonged by keeping exactly the same value of EP granted.
Shaman.totemDescription:
The knight can materialize their AI into one or more bodies. These are roughly detailed and resemble the knight's meta-armour, but in a pixelated or poorly crafted version. These bodies are named 'totems' and can help the knight in many tasks. They are energetically very costly to materialize and maintain. The AI can, of course, suffer the effects of imprinting when it is in one or more totems. The totems must remain within medium range of the knight to exist. They can assist in all tasks, but are extremely sensitive to all forms of aggression. The slightest violent shock simply makes them disappear. The totems can move, act with precision, communicate, but they cannot act without orders from the knight, nor take initiative.

The knight can materialize totems. In game terms, a totem is simply destroyed by an attack that targets it (attacks that target it automatically hit, as a totem does not defend itself). The knight can use their totems to add one of their additional characteristics per totem, without overdrives, to a test they perform. As with assistance, the characteristics must be different each time. They can be used in combat or for any other action. The totems can be used for most tests, but the PC must always argue for their use and use them with the GM's agreement.
Shaman.impregnationDescription:
The AI risks suffering imprinting and therefore can no longer be dispossessed of the body in which it incarnates. These points accumulate.

After the first time, the knight must make a test to deploy their AI with minimal risk. The difficulty of the test is equal to the number of points accumulated by the GM.

Points can be removed from this total if the knight takes care of their AI or if the AI is not deployed for a certain time, at the GM's discretion. The accumulated points are reset to 0 at the beginning of each mission or intermission.
Shaman.n0EvolutionsDescription: Now, a maximum of three totems can be materialized at the same time.
Shaman.n0EvolutionsAscensionDuration: One scene or one phase of conflict, can be extended by keeping exactly the same value of EP granted.
Shaman.n1EvolutionsDescription: Now, the Ascension mode can be activated even when the knight is out of their meta-armour. In this case, the AI of the meta-armour takes the appearance of the knight in a Guardian suit or in meta-armour, at the knight's choice.
Shaman.n1EvolutionsAscensionDuration: One scene or one phase of conflict, can be extended by keeping exactly the same value of EP granted.
Shaman.n2EvolutionsDescription: Now, the totems can act independently (always following the knight's orders) and without range limits. They are much more finely materialized and resemble the knight's meta-armour in every detail. They can also be materialized for an entire scene or an entire phase of conflict for a total cost of 10 EP.
Shaman.n2EvolutionsAscensionDuration: One scene or one phase of conflict, can be extended by keeping exactly the same value of EP granted.

Berserk.name: Berserk
Berserk.description:
Created just after humanity's victory over the Wild Hunt, the Berserk meta-armour was designed around the luminous heart of an angelic being killed during the Battle of Rome. In appearance, it is a gleaming and armoured suit, designed to project and conduct light in all directions around its wearer. It is the ultimate meta-armour of Avalon, and Merlin, like Gauvain, hopes that it will be the last. Unfortunately, it is a unique creation, requiring a heart of light to function. Only one Berserk meta-armour is in Avalon's possession.

The light of the Berserk's heart is not light in the strict sense. It is a strange matter, the full properties of which remain unknown, and which can be sometimes almost solid, sometimes vaporous, sometimes ethereal. Merlin named this matter 'apeiron energy' and that of the heart itself 'apeiron element' in opposition to the alpha element.



Despite its cutting-edge design, the Berserk meta-armour is equipped with relatively weak armour and force field. The alpha element and energy fields support the presence of the heart of light very poorly, so it was necessary to limit the presence of dark metal and replace it with more traditional materials, such as graphene carbon nanotubes or a state-of-the-art gold-platinum alloy. The Berserk compensates for these weaknesses with an innate resistance to the attacks and abilities of the Anathema.

The Berserk meta-armour was crafted to fight against darkness, not humans. By analysing the heart of the creature of light, Merlin was able to understand that the apeiron energy emanating from it could be manipulated, diffracted, modified to activate several different effects that could disrupt enemies, injure them, annihilate them, and even strengthen allies. The light of the Berserk is also made of heat and fury. The knight can let these feelings burst forth to enter a terrifying rage, capable of allowing him to defeat any creature of darkness. However, when enraged, the knight is no longer in control of himself.

Finally, the heart is endowed with an energy that virtually never runs out and is not quantifiable. However, it is irrevocably linked to the will of the meta-armour's wearer. Without the latter's hope, the apeiron energy core cannot function at its full potential. As a result, each ability of the meta-armour costs hope to its wearer, and the only effective way for him to recover it is to annihilate the spawns of darkness, as if only destruction and anger could strengthen the knight's will.



This meta-armour has capabilities that do not draw from energy, but directly from the knight's hope. All its modules, weapons, and effects that would normally draw EP do so from hope points instead. However, each cost in hope points when using modules and weapons is halved, with a minimum of 1 hope point used.

APEIRON CORE

As long as he wears the meta-armour, the character increases his total hope points by 15 points. Additionally, all his hope losses (excluding those caused by the meta-armour's abilities) are reduced by 1. The effect is cumulative with other advantages or effects.

BEARER OF LIGHT

All attacks made by the knight in meta-armour receive the effects: anti-Anathema and tenebricide.
Berserk.illuminationDescription:
The apeiron energy released by the core of the meta-armour can be deployed all around it to cause different effects. Depending on the intensity of the light or its state, six different effects can be applied. All effects of this mode, except Candle, can be prolonged for the cost in hope points indicated.

Attention: Upon obtaining the meta-armour, the knight must choose three of the seven effects listed here and can use them. He can only obtain the others through the evolutions of the meta-armour.
Berserk.illuminationBeaconDescription: The light glowing from the armour strengthens the determination of allies, making them more aggressive. As long as the effect is activated, when a PC or ally within short range of the armour makes a test, they receive automatic successes on rolls made against creatures of the Anathema (combat, pursuit, etc.).
Berserk.illuminationBlazeDescription:
The light around the armour can be shaped into burning volutes that injure creatures of the Anathema within contact range.

As long as the effect is activated, creatures of the Anathema within contact range of the armour suffer damage and violence each turn in the conflict phase or every 6 seconds during a scene. The shield score is ignored. Additionally, darkness of the night or twilight type moves away to short range.
Berserk.illuminationCandleDescription:
The Berserk meta-armour can deploy small sparks of soft and warm light that allow an ally to recover hope.

By sacrificing hope points (with no possible reduction), the knight can give the same number of hope points to an ally, PC or NPC.
Berserk.illuminationLanternDescription:
A soft and reassuring light emanates from the meta-armour. It motivates allies and even seems able to annihilate despair.

As long as the effect is active, the desperate within short range of the meta-armour suffer damage with associated effects.
Berserk.illuminationLighthouseDescription:
The light of the meta-armour pulses and troubles the nearest creatures of the Anathema. The flow that exists between them is like torn and significantly diminished by the apeiron energy.

As long as the effect is activated, hostile creatures of the Anathema within short range lose an action during their game turn.
Berserk.illuminationProjectorDescription:
The light emanating from the core of the meta-armour can be concentrated on a creature of the Anathema in a powerful beam. In full light, the horrible nature of the target changes, it seems to become more beautiful and detach from the darkness.

As long as the effect is activated, the targeted creature within short range, hostile or scoundrel, can no longer use one of its abilities. The ability can be chosen by the knight, but he must have identified it and be able to describe its effects. Otherwise, the GM chooses.
Berserk.illuminationTorchDescription: The light solidifies around the character, creating a kind of luminous mist. Humans and animals that are not desperate and are within short range receive an aegis score or increase their aegis score when they are targeted by creatures or effects of the Anathema. Additionally, darkness within short range of the armour is considered to be of a lesser intensity level. Darkness becomes night, night becomes twilight, and twilight simply disappears.
Berserk.rageDescription:
To recover hope points, the knight must feed the light of the meta-armour. The apeiron energy can only be fueled by the sacrifice of a creature of the Anathema or other, as if the very act of devouring something could make it endure.

By activating this mode, the knight lets himself be invaded by the light of the meta-armour and tries to revive his own hope as well as the energy of its core. He then enters a rage and is inhabited by the light that emanates from him in a burning and brilliant smoke. This mode can only be activated during the conflict phase. The effects of the Illumination mode can be used simultaneously.

By activating this mode, the character can enter different levels of rage that make him suffer increasingly powerful, but also increasingly dangerous effects. Note that each level of rage reached possesses the effects of the previous level. To reach a higher level of rage, the knight must kill an enemy or sacrifice 1D6 hope points (with no possible reduction).
Berserk.rageBlazeDescription:
The light around the armour can be shaped into burning volutes that injure creatures of the Anathema within contact range.

As long as the effect is activated, creatures of the Anathema within contact range of the armour suffer damage and violence each turn in the conflict phase or every 6 seconds during a scene. The shield score is ignored. Additionally, darkness of the night or twilight type moves away to short range.
Berserk.rageFureurDescription:
The level is not cumulative with the previous one, but it cancels and replaces the previous one (the cumulative effects are already calculated)

He can no longer lose hope points outside the cost of his abilities.

He must attack the nearest creature of darkness or enemy by approaching as closely as possible.

He automatically kills or puts an enemy into agony that he should simply incapacitate.

He ignores the effects of shock X, interference X, domination, and anathema.

All creatures of the Anathema within contact range attack the PC instead of following their tactics. The effect of the Banner module overrides this effect.
Berserk.rageNourriDescription: When he is in Rage mode, each creature or human being that the knight kills makes him recover a certain number of hope points. Additionally, if a creature of darkness is killed within short range of the armour, he recovers 1 hope point as long as he is in this mode.
Berserk.rageRageDescription:
The level is not cumulative with the previous one, but it cancels and replaces the previous one (the cumulative effects are already calculated)

He can no longer lose hope points outside the cost of his abilities.

He must attack the nearest creature of darkness or enemy by approaching as closely as possible.

He automatically kills or puts an enemy into agony that he should simply incapacitate.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsDescription:
As long as they wear the meta-armour, the character now increases their total hope points by 25.

They receive an additional effect of their choice from the Illumination mode.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationBeaconDescriptio: The light glowing from the armour strengthens the determination of allies, making them more aggressive. As long as the effect is activated, when a PC or ally within short range of the armour makes a test, they receive automatic successes on rolls made against creatures of the Anathema (combat, pursuit, etc.).
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationBlazeDescription:
The light around the armour can be shaped into burning volutes that injure creatures of the Anathema within contact range.

As long as the effect is activated, creatures of the Anathema within contact range of the armour suffer damage and violence each turn in the conflict phase or every 6 seconds during a scene. The shield score is ignored. Additionally, darkness of the night or twilight type moves away to short range.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationCandleDescriptio:
The Berserk meta-armour can deploy small sparks of soft and warm light that allow an ally to recover hope.

By sacrificing hope points (with no possible reduction), the knight can give the same number of hope points to an ally, PC or NPC.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationLanternDescripti:
A soft and reassuring light emanates from the meta-armour. It motivates allies and even seems able to annihilate despair.

As long as the effect is active, the desperate within short range of the meta-armour suffer damage with associated effects.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationLighthouseDescri:
The light of the meta-armour pulses and troubles the nearest creatures of the Anathema. The flow that exists between them is like torn and significantly diminished by the apeiron energy.

As long as the effect is activated, hostile creatures of the Anathema within short range lose an action during their game turn.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationProjectorDescrip:
The light emanating from the core of the meta-armour can be concentrated on a creature of the Anathema in a powerful beam. In full light, the horrible nature of the target changes, it seems to become more beautiful and detach from the darkness.

As long as the effect is activated, the targeted creature within short range, hostile or scoundrel, can no longer use one of its abilities. The ability can be chosen by the knight, but they must have identified it and be able to describe its effects. Otherwise, the GM chooses.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsIlluminationTorchDescription: The light solidifies around the character, creating a kind of luminous mist. Humans and animals that are not desperate and are within short range receive an aegis score or increase their aegis score when they are targeted by creatures or effects of the Anathema. Additionally, darkness within short range of the armour is considered to be of a lesser intensity level. Darkness becomes night, night becomes twilight, and twilight simply disappears.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsRageBlazeDescription:
The light around the armour can be shaped into burning volutes that injure creatures of the Anathema within contact range.

As long as the effect is activated, creatures of the Anathema within contact range of the armour suffer damage and violence each turn in the conflict phase or every 6 seconds during a scene. The shield score is ignored. Additionally, darkness of the night or twilight type moves away to short range.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsRageFureurDescription:
The level is not cumulative with the previous one, but it cancels and replaces the previous one (the cumulative effects are already calculated)

They can no longer lose hope points outside the cost of their abilities.

They must attack the nearest creature of darkness or enemy by approaching as closely as possible.

They automatically kill or put an enemy into agony that they should simply incapacitate.

They ignore the effects of shock X, interference X, domination, and anathema.

All creatures of the Anathema within contact range attack the PC instead of following their tactics. The effect of the Banner module overrides this effect.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsRageNourriDescription: When they are in Rage mode, each creature or human being that the knight kills makes them recover a certain number of hope points. Additionally, if a creature of darkness is killed within short range of the armour, they recover 1 hope point as long as they are in this mode.
Berserk.n0EvolutionsRageRageDescription:
The level is not cumulative with the previous one, but it cancels and replaces the previous one (the cumulative effects are already calculated)

They can no longer lose hope points outside the cost of their abilities.

They must attack the nearest creature of darkness or enemy by approaching as closely as possible.

They automatically kill or put an enemy into agony that they should simply incapacitate.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsDescription:
The effects Beacon, Blaze, and Torch increase in efficiency:

  • Blaze now causes 4D6 (12) points of damage and violence.
  • Beacon now grants a bonus of 4 automatic successes.
  • Torch now offers an aegis of 4 or an aegis bonus of 4.

The knight receives an additional effect of their choice from the Illumination mode.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationBeaconDescriptio: The light glowing from the armour strengthens the determination of allies, making them more aggressive. As long as the effect is activated, when a PC or ally within short range of the armour makes a test, they receive automatic successes on rolls made against creatures of the Anathema (combat, pursuit, etc.).
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationBlazeDescription:
The light around the armour can be shaped into burning volutes that injure creatures of the Anathema within contact range.

As long as the effect is activated, creatures of the Anathema within contact range of the armour suffer damage and violence each turn in the conflict phase or every 6 seconds during a scene. The shield score is ignored. Additionally, darkness of the night or twilight type moves away to short range.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationCandleDescriptio:
The Berserk meta-armour can deploy small sparks of soft and warm light that allow an ally to recover hope.

By sacrificing hope points (with no possible reduction), the knight can give the same number of hope points to an ally, PC or NPC.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationLanternDescripti:
A soft and reassuring light emanates from the meta-armour. It motivates allies and even seems able to annihilate despair.

As long as the effect is active, the desperate within short range of the meta-armour suffer damage with associated effects.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationLighthouseDescri:
The light of the meta-armour pulses and troubles the nearest creatures of the Anathema. The flow that exists between them is like torn and significantly diminished by the apeiron energy.

As long as the effect is activated, hostile creatures of the Anathema within short range lose an action during their game turn.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationProjectorDescrip:
The light emanating from the core of the meta-armour can be concentrated on a creature of the Anathema in a powerful beam. In full light, the horrible nature of the target changes, it seems to become more beautiful and detach from the darkness.

As long as the effect is activated, the targeted creature within short range, hostile or scoundrel, can no longer use one of its abilities. The ability can be chosen by the knight, but they must have identified it and be able to describe its effects. Otherwise, the GM chooses.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsIlluminationTorchDescription: The light solidifies around the character, creating a kind of luminous mist. Humans and animals that are not desperate and are within short range receive an aegis score or increase their aegis score when they are targeted by creatures or effects of the Anathema. Additionally, darkness within short range of the armour is considered to be of a lesser intensity level. Darkness becomes night, night becomes twilight, and twilight simply disappears.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsRageBlazeDescription:
The light around the armour can be shaped into burning volutes that injure creatures of the Anathema within contact range.

As long as the effect is activated, creatures of the Anathema within contact range of the armour suffer damage and violence each turn in the conflict phase or every 6 seconds during a scene. The shield score is ignored. Additionally, darkness of the night or twilight type moves away to short range.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsRageFureurDescription:
The level is not cumulative with the previous one, but it cancels and replaces the previous one (the cumulative effects are already calculated)

They can no longer lose hope points outside the cost of their abilities.

They must attack the nearest creature of darkness or enemy by approaching as closely as possible.

They automatically kill or put an enemy into agony that they should simply incapacitate.

They ignore the effects of shock X, interference X, domination, and anathema.

All creatures of the Anathema within contact range attack the PC instead of following their tactics. The effect of the Banner module overrides this effect.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsRageNourriDescription: When they are in Rage mode, each creature or human being that the knight kills makes them recover a certain number of hope points. Additionally, if a creature of darkness is killed within short range of the armour, they recover 1 hope point as long as they are in this mode.
Berserk.n1EvolutionsRageRageDescription:
The level is not cumulative with the previous one, but it cancels and replaces the previous one (the cumulative effects are already calculated)

They can no longer lose hope points outside the cost of their abilities.

They must attack the nearest creature of darkness or enemy by approaching as closely as possible.

They automatically kill or put an enemy into agony that they should simply incapacitate.
Berserk.n2EvolutionsDescription:
Now, all of the character's hope losses (excluding those caused by the meta-armour's abilities) are reduced by 3 (minimum 1). The effect is cumulative with other advantages or effects.

They receive an additional effect of their choice from the Illumination mode.
Berserk.n2EvolutionsIlluminationBeaconDescriptio: The light glowing from the armour strengthens the determination of allies, making them more aggressive. As long as the effect is activated, when a PC or ally within short range of the armour makes a test, they receive automatic successes on rolls made against creatures of the Anathema (combat, pursuit, etc.).
